awd_titl_txt: From Wastewater to Gasoline - Aqueous Biorefining of Polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB)-Enriched Biosolids
awd_abstract_narration:
Increasing population and rising living standards are driving the demand for more clean water and inexpensive energy, materials, and food. At the same time, this demand produces growing volumes of solid and liquid wastes that public utilities must manage. Current approaches to wastewater treatment expend large amounts of energy to remove organic carbon, nutrients, and pathogens from the water. However, these same "waste" constituents can potentially be recovered as energy or other valuable products during the wastewater treatment process. Recent research demonstrates that wastewater treatment can be accomplished using microorganisms that funnel waste organic carbon into their cells to form polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB) granules. The PHBs can then be separated from the resulting waste and converted to high-value products such as renewable gasoline, industrial chemicals, and bioplastics. Through integration of biological and catalytic technologies, the wastewater treatment processe can be reinvented as a "bio-refinery" that yields clean water as just one product of many. This re-invention of water infrastructure will also allow the diffusion of sustainable waste treatment and resource management concepts to a broader audience of students at all levels. Ultimately, such research and educational efforts are needed to support the Nation's shift towards more sustainable infrastructure.

Motivated by developments in nascent biorefinery technologies, this project aims to realize and optimize the conversion of waste organic carbon streams to valuable industrial chemicals and gasoline-grade hydrocarbon fuels through the processing of PHB-enriched biomass. Experiments will be conducted to: (1) develop effective strategies for separating PHB from microbial biomass and promoting PHB depolymerization in an aqueous environment; (2) identify reaction conditions and catalysts for optimal dehydration and decarboxylation of the resultant PHB-derived monomers; and (3) demonstrate integrated conversion of waste organic carbon to gasoline-grade fuels and establish a techno-economic analysis (TEA) framework for the system. PHB separation from biomass and subsequent depolymerization will focus on aqueous-only strategies to minimize chemical inputs and byproduct wastes. Catalyst development will focus on low-cost solid acid catalysts (SACs) such as zeolites. The most promising catalysts will be evaluated in continuous flow reactors, and both preventative and regenerative strategies for maintaining catalyst activity will be tested. This research will support a path forward towards increased valorization of organic carbon-rich waste streams in municipal, agricultural, and industrial sectors, potentially flipping the energy balance and cost model for wastewater utilities. In addition, this project supports the career development of graduate and undergraduate student participants, and educational and outreach activities designed for K-12 students and teachers will support the diffusion of sustainable waste treatment and renewable energy production methods to a larger audience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was funded by the Environmental Engineering Program in the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems (CBET) Division at the National Science Foundation to investigate innovative strategies for converting waste organic materials into valuable industrial chemicals and gasoline-grade fuels. Increasing population and rising living standards are driving the demand for more clean water and inexpensive energy, materials, and food. At the same time, society is generating growing volumes of solid and liquid waste. Our current approaches to managing these wastes are costly and expend large amounts of energy. By some estimates, approximately three percent of electricity is used for treatment of wastewater that is released from homes and businesses in the U.S. each year. Viewed from a different perspective, however, these same "wastes" contain a great deal of energy and other resources like nutrients that can potentially be recovered during the processes for waste treatment.

This project investigated the use of innovative hydrothermal and catalytic technologies to realize the conversion of waste organic carbon materials into potentially valuable industrial chemicals and liquid fuels that can replace non-renewable petroleum sources. Other researchers have recently reported that microorganisms feeding on waste organic carbon can efficiently accumulate carbon within their cells as the biopolymer polyhydroxybutyrate (PHB). In this project, we were able to show how PHB can be further upgraded into propylene, a valuable industrial chemical, through reactions in hydrothermal water (liquid water at elevated temperatures and pressures) and vapor-phase reactions taking place on solid acid catalysts. Experiments revealed the individual steps and mechanisms that limit these reactions, an outcome that will be critical to future efforts to integrate these processes into “wastewater” biorefineries. Another important outcome of the project was the identification of effective catalyst materials and procedures for sustaining catalyst activity that provide a pathway forward for translating these technologies from the laboratory into practice.

Waste fats, oils, and greases, collectively referred to as FOGs, are another waste organic material that is challenging to manage using conventional approaches to wastewater treatment. These materials, including large volumes derived from food and restaurant wastes, contain a combination of oily fatty acid chemicals that are energy rich, but incompatible with traditional liquid fuels (e.g., gasoline).  They can be converted to hydrocarbon fuels with a composition similar to petroleum-derived diesel through catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reactions, but HDO catalysts used in the petroleum industry are incompatible with the water that often accompanies waste FOGs. Recent reports have shown that fatty acids can be converted to hydrocarbon fuels in hydrothermal water, but these reactions required use of platinum-containing catalyst materials. However, the high cost and environmental scarcity of platinum and related materials represents a major barrier to the use of catalytic processes for waste management, so efforts to identify low-cost and earth-abundant catalyst materials and procedures for sustaining their activity is critical to their widespread adoption. An important outcome of this project was the identification of much lower cost catalyst materials, including materials based on earth-abundant nickel. Experimental work characterized the importance of catalyst formulation and operating conditions, for example temperature and time, on the efficiency of fatty acid-to-fuel conversion reactions. Another important outcome was the demonstration that expensive and unsustainable external supplies of hydrogen gas (typically produced from petroleum sources) can be replaced in these hydrothermal catalytic processes through the conversion of other common components found in waste mixtures, including glycerol and methanol, into hydrogen within the same reactor. 

Project research was also used as a vehicle to engage K-12 students in activities designed to interest students in STEM subjects and careers. Participating graduate students gained valuable teaching experience leading outreach activities at a camp for children with dyslexia. Campers learned about organic waste streams and waste valorization, the environmental impacts of the food system and opportunities to minimize food related waste while taking part in a food waste tie dye activity. Activities were also adapted for use at local elementary school science nights.

Findings from this project resulted in several peer-reviewed journal publications and was included in presentations at a number of professional conferences attended by other researchers and practitioners. Moreover, the project supported the education and professional development of four PhD students. One PhD graduate is now employed as a tenure-track faculty member, where she is building on findings of this project through a combination of experimental and modeling research. Participation in the project supported another PhD student’s passion for reducing food waste. While working on the project, she also served as President of a student organization focused on fighting hunger, reducing food waste, and promoting healthier eating habits in the local community. During her tenure as President, the organization was awarded the Gold Mine Award by the local community and supported efforts to secure funding for a campus food pantry that will ensure continuous local meat and produce availability on campus.
